{{Infobox Military Structure |name=Citadel of Saigon |location=[[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]], [[Vietnam]] |coordinates= |image= |caption= |type=Square [[Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban|Vauban]] |code= |built=1790 |builder=[[Gia Long|Nguyễn Phúc Ánh]], [[Nguyễn Dynasty]] |materials=Granite, brick, earth (1835 version) |height={{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} |used=1790–1859 |demolished=1859 |condition=Destroyed by [[French Navy]] in 1859 siege |ownership= |open_to_public= |controlledby=[[Nguyễn Dynasty]] |garrison= |current_commander= |commanders= |occupants= |battles=[[Lê Văn Khôi revolt]], [[Colonization of Cochinchina]] |events= }} The '''Citadel of Saigon''' ({{lang-vi|Thành Sài Gòn}} {{IPA-vi|tʰâːn ʂâj ɣɔ̂n|}}) also known as the '''Citadel of Gia Dinh''' ({{lang-vi|Thành Gia Định}} {{IPA-vi|tʰâːn ʒaː dîˀn|}}) was a late 18th-century fortress that stood in [[Ho Chi Minh City|Saigon]] (also known in the 19th century as Gia Dinh, now Ho Chi Minh City), [[Vietnam]] from its construction in 1790 until its destruction in February 1859. It was destroyed in a [[French Navy|French naval]] bombardment as part of the [[colonization of Cochinchina|colonisation of southern Vietnam]] which became the French colony of [[Cochinchina]]. The citadel was only used once prior to its destruction, when it was captured by [[Le Van Khoi]] in 1833 and used in a revolt against Emperor [[Minh Mạng]].
In the late 18th century, the city of [[Saigon]] was the subject of warfare between the [[Tây Sơn Dynasty]], which had toppled the [[Nguyễn Lords]] who ruled southern Vietnam, and [[Gia Long|Nguyễn Ánh]], the nephew of the last Nguyen Lord. The city changed hands multiple times before Nguyễn Ánh captured the city in 1789. Under the directions of French officers recruited for him, a [[Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban|Vauban]] style "octagonal" citadel was built in 1790. Thereafter, the Tây Sơn never attacked southern Vietnam again, and the military protection allowed Nguyen Anh to get a foothold in the region. He used this to build an administration and strengthen his forces for a campaign that united Vietnam in 1802, resulting in his coronation as Gia Long.
In 1833, his son Minh Mạng was faced with a rebellion led by Lê Văn Khôi, which started after the tomb of Khôi's father Lê Văn Duyệt was desecrated by imperial officials. The rebels took control of the citadel and the revolt continued until the imperial forces took control of the citadel in 1835. Following the capture of the citadel, Minh Mang ordered its razing and replacement with a smaller square stone-built structure, that was more vulnerable to attacks. On February 17, 1859, the citadel was captured during the French invasion after less than a day of battle and significant amounts of military supplies were seized. Realising that they did not have the capacity to hold the fort against Vietnamese attempts to recapture it, the French razed it with explosives, before withdrawing their troops.
== Background == {{see also|Gia Long}} Until the 17th century, what is now southern Vietnam was not inhabited by ethnic [[Vietnamese people|Vietnamese]] but by [[Khmer people]]. What is now central Vietnam had been the seat of the kingdom of [[Champa]], which fought the kingdom of [[Đại Việt]] over many centuries. The [[1471 Vietnamese conquest of Champa]] saw the destruction of the Cham capital and heralded the ultimate decline of Champa. The Vietnamese continually expanded south in what is known as the ''nam tien'' (''southward march''). Central Vietnam was ruled by the [[Nguyễn lords]], who had broken away in the early 17th century from the [[Trịnh lords]], who ruled the north. The Nguyễn continued the southward expansion that eventually saw Vietnamese encroach into what had been Khmer territory in the [[Mekong Delta]]. The southern edge of Vietnam, being further away from the Nguyễn power base in the centre, was loosely governed.<ref>McLeod, pp. 2–8.</ref>
[[File:GiaLong.jpg|thumb|left|Nguyễn Ánh, the future Emperor Gia Long]] In 1771, the [[Tây Sơn rebellion]] erupted from [[Bình Định Province]].<ref name="m520">Mantienne, p. 520.</ref> In 1777, the last of the Nguyễn lords was deposed and killed.<ref>Hall, p. 426.</ref> His nephew Nguyen Phuc Anh was the most senior member of the Nguyễn family to have survived the Tây Sơn victory and conquest of Saigon in 1777.<ref name="h423">Hall, p. 423.</ref><ref name="c282">Cady, p. 282.</ref><ref name="b266"/> Nguyễn Ánh fled to [[Hà Tiên]] in the far south of the country, where he met [[Pigneau de Behaine]],<ref name="m520"/><ref name="m7">McLeod, p. 7.</ref><ref name="k75">Karnow, p. 75.</ref> a French priest who became his adviser and played a large part in his rise to power.<ref name="k75"/> Over the next few decades, there were continuous attacks and counterattacks by both sides and Saigon changed hands frequently.<ref name="m520"/><ref>Buttinger, pp. 233–241.</ref><ref>Hall, pp. 426–429.</ref> Eventually, Nguyễn Ánh was forced him into exile.<ref name="m520"/> The Tây Sơn regularly raided the rice growing areas of the south during the harvesting season, confiscating the Nguyễns' supply of food.<ref name="m520" />
In 1788, the Tây Sơn moved north to attack the Trịnh and unite Vietnam. Nguyễn Ánh took advantage of the situation to return to southern Vietnam.<ref name="c282"/><ref name="h430"/> After rebuilding his army, he recaptured Saigon on September 7, 1788.<ref name="h430"/> His grip on the south was enhanced by a group of Frenchmen and equipment that Pigneau had recruited, although the magnitude of the aid has been the source of dispute.<ref name="c282"/><ref name="b266">Buttinger, p. 266.</ref><ref name="h430">Hall, p. 430.</ref><ref name="h429">Hall, p. 429.</ref><ref name="c283">Cady, p. 283.</ref><ref name="k77">Karnow, p. 77.</ref><ref name="m11">McLeod, p. 11.</ref><ref name="m521">Mantienne, p. 521.</ref>
Having seen Saigon slip from his hands on many occasions in the previous decade,<ref name="m520"/> Nguyễn Ánh was keen to strengthen his hold on the key southern city, turning it into his capital,<ref name="m522"/> and the base for his preparations for his planned conquest of the Tây Sơn and Vietnam. His enemies had regularly raided the area and confiscated the rice harvest.<ref name="m522"/>
== Construction == The French officers recruited by Pigneau were used to train Nguyễn Ánh's armed forces and introduce their technological expertise to the war effort.<ref name="h430"/> [[Olivier de Puymanel]] was responsible for the construction of fortifications.<ref name="h430"/><ref name="k77"/><ref name="c284">Cady, p. 284.</ref> One of Nguyễn Ánh's first actions was to ask the French officers to design and oversee the construction of a modern European-style citadel in Saigon. The citadel was designed by Theodore Lebrun and de Puymanel and 30,000 people were used to construct it in 1790.<ref name="m522"/> The townfolk and their mandarins were heavily taxed for the work, and the labourers were worked to the extent that it provoked a revolt.<ref name="m522"/>
== First structure == [[File:Citadel of Saigon before 1835.png|thumb|300px|Layout of the original citadel. Before 1835, the citadel of Saigon was also called ''Thành Bát Quái'' (Citadel of Eight Trigrams) or ''Thành Quy'' (Citadel of Tortoise) because of this layout.]] [[File:Citadel of Saigon 1867.png|thumb|300px|Layout of the citadel 1867]]
The stone and earth citadel eventually had a perimeter measuring {{convert|4176|m|abbr=on}} in a [[Sébastien Le Prestre de Vauban|Vauban]] model.<ref name="m522">Mantienne, p. 522.</ref> It was described as being of a Chinese style, designed in the octagonal form of a lotus flower, with eight gates<ref name="m522"/> in the '' Ðại Nam nhất thống chí'', the official records of the Nguyen Dynasty.<ref name="m523"/> However, such records are believed to have been written metaphorically, rather than literally. Two French maps of the city, drawn by de Puymanel and Jean-Marie Dayot—another senior officer<ref name="h430"/>—in 1799 and 1815 respectively, show a square-shaped design, with four main towers at the corners, and six outer half-towers. Louis Malleret said that "it is impossible to see any octagonal design in this".<ref name="m523">Mantienne, p. 523.</ref>
The design suggested by the French maps is corroborated by the accounts of British and American visitors who travelled to Saigon seeking trade deals for their respective countries in the 1820s. British trade envoy [[John Crawfurd]] wrote that "the citadel of Saigon...is, in form, a parallelogram...I conjecture, from appearance, that the longest side of the square may be about three-quarters of a mile in length".<ref name="m523"/><ref name="cr223">Crawfurd, p. 223.</ref> George Finlayson, a naturalist and surgeon who travelled to southern Vietnam as a member of a trade delegation from the [[British East India Company]], described the fortress as being "of square form, and each side is about half a mile in extent".<ref name="m523"/> Lieutenant John White of the United States Navy, travelling as a trade envoy for the United States, claimed to have seen only four of the eight gates, but Crawfurd wrote that "With the exception of the four principal gateways...the gates consist of four large and as many small ones".<ref name="m523"/> The four small gates observed by Crawfurd are in accord with the design principles of Vauban.<ref name="m523"/>
The two French maps of the citadel show a Vauban structure, as do the accounts of the trade delegates. According to Crawfurd, "the original plan appears to have been European, but left incomplete. It has a regular glacis, an esplanade, a dry ditch of considerable breadth, and regular ramparts and bastion...The interior is neatly laid out and clean, and presents an appearance of European order and arrangement."<ref name="cr223"/><ref name="m524"/> Finlayson described the citadel as having been "constructed of late years, on the principles of European fortification. It is furnished with a regular [[glacis]], wet ditch, and a high [[Defensive wall|rampart]], and commands the surrounding country."<ref name="m524"/> Lebrun and de Puymanel did not choose the site for the citadel, instead using the compound of a fort. The location was seen as ideal for such a purpose. It was of substantial elevation, with three sides bordered by natural waterways at right angles: the [[Saigon River]], Arroyo Chinois and the Arroyo de l'Avalanche.<ref name="m524"/> Crawfurd reported that the walls were made of earth that was "covered everywhere with a green sward".<ref name="cr224">Crawfurd, p. 224.</ref> White estimated that the height of walls was around {{convert|6|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="w220">White, p. 220.</ref> According to Crawfurd, the gateways were built from stone and lime, with the towers being of Chinese architecture with a double-canopied appearance.<ref name="cr224"/> The approach towards the gates include a zig-zag in the glacis.<ref name="cr224"/>
The location was in complete fulfilment of the requirements of geomancy, with a north-west/south-east orientation. The three courses of water provided the "vital energy".<ref name="m524"/> As three waterways formed right angles, the square structure was the most suitable. The aspect of the citadel closest to a Chinese style was the decoration of the gates, which Finlayson noted as "handsome and ornamented in the Chinese style".<ref name="m524"/> White recalled that the gates were reinforced by iron, a style that was common in Europe. The citadel was bordered on three sides by pre-existing waterways, increasing its defensive capacity.<ref name="m524">Mantienne, p. 524.</ref>
Nguyễn Ánh located his headquarters and palace inside the walls of the citadel. The palace itself was estimated by White to have covered an area of {{convert|3.25|ha|acre|1}}, standing at the centre of the citadel on a green, enclosed by paling.<ref name="w220"/> The structure was approximately {{convert|30|m|abbr=on}} long and {{convert|18|m|abbr=on}}, built from brick and standing on a foundation around {{convert|1.8|m|abbr=on}} above the ground, with a wooden staircase.<ref name="w220"/> Each of the four sides of the palace was defended by a watchtower that stood approximately {{convert|9|m|abbr=on}}.<ref name="w220"/> After Nguyễn Ánh became emperor, he established his capital in Hue, and no longer used the palace,<ref name="w221"/> which was used by the governor of the southern region.<ref name="w220"/> The administration quarters continued to be used by the provincial mandarins and their paperwork was archived within.<ref name="w221">White, p. 221.</ref> A cemetery stood at the western end of the citadel, with prominent mandarins being interred there, while the arsenal was located in the northeast section in six large buildings. Soldiers lived in huts that were built throughout the grounds of the citadel.<ref name="w225">White, p. 225.</ref> White estimated that the fort was equipped with around 250 cannons, primarily made of brass.<ref name="w224">White, p. 224.</ref>
== Impact on the Tây Sơn and the Nguyễn == Following the construction of the citadel, the Tây Sơn never again attempted to recapture the city—the building gave Nguyen Anh a further psychological advantage over his opponents.<ref name="m525">Mantienne, p. 525.</ref> The citadel helped to secure the southern region, which allowed Nguyễn Ánh to implement domestic programs to strengthen himself economically in preparation to fight the Tây Sơn. He used the newfound security to undertake agrarian reforms.<ref name="m8">McLeod, p. 8.</ref> Due to Tây Sơn naval raids on the rice crop, the area had been suffering long term rice shortages.<ref name="m530">Mantienne, p. 530.</ref> Although the land was extremely fertile, the region was agriculturally underexploited because it had been occupied by Vietnamese people only relatively recently. Nguyễn Ánh's programs resulted in large amounts of previously idle land being cultivated. Large surpluses of grain, taxable by the state, were generated.<ref name="m8"/>
By 1800, the increased agricultural productivity allowed Nguyễn Ánh to support an army of more than 30,000 soldiers and a navy of more than 1,200 vessels. The surplus from the state granary was used to facilitate the importing of supplies for military purposes.<ref name="m9">McLeod, p. 9.</ref> Eventually, Nguyễn Ánh moved northwards and in 1802 he conquered all of Vietnam and became emperor, ruling under the name of [[Gia Long]].<ref name="k77"/><ref name="h431">Hall, p. 431.</ref><ref name="b241">Buttinger, p. 241.</ref>
== Lê Văn Khôi revolt == {{main|Lê Văn Khôi revolt}} [[File:MinhMang.jpg|thumb|Emperor Minh Mạng]] The citadel was not used during the rule of Gia Long and the only military action occurred after his son had ascended the throne as [[Minh Mạng]].<ref name="m524"/> Years of tension between the monarch and General [[Lê Văn Duyệt]], the governor of southern Vietnam,<ref>McLeod, pp. 24–29.</ref> came to a head after the death of the latter in 1831.<ref name="m29">McLeod, p. 29.</ref> Tension between the pair surfaced when Gia Long made Minh Mang the heir to the throne. Duyet had opposed the succession, favouring the enthronement of a young son of the late [[Nguyễn Phúc Cảnh |Prince Cảnh]], the eldest of Gia Long's sons.<ref name="m24">McLeod, p. 24.</ref>
After Gia Long's death, Minh Mạng and Duyệt clashed frequently. As the southern governor, Duyet had significant autonomy,<ref name="m24"/> as only the centre of Vietnam was under direct royal rule.<ref name="m16">McLeod, p. 16.</ref> Duyet was a supporter of Catholic missionaries, while Minh Mạng was a staunch Confucianist.<ref name="m24"/> Duyet often disobeyed Minh Mạng's orders,<ref name="m28">McLeod, p. 28.</ref> and the emperor attempted to reduce the Duyet's autonomous power, which became easier with the general's death in 1831.<ref name="m29"/> The governor's post was abolished and the region was put under direct control.<ref name="m29"/>
Following the integration of southern Vietnam into the central administration, newly appointed imperial officials arrived in Saigon. The new mandarins carried out a detailed inquiry into Duyệt's rule and claimed that widespread corruption and abuse of power took place.<ref name="m29"/> [[Bạch Xuân Nguyên]], the head of the inquiry, called for Duyet's posthumous prosecution, which resulted in 100 lashes being applied to his grave.<ref name="m30"/><ref name="b"/> Many of Duyệt's subordinates were arrested and 16 of his family members were executed.<ref name="m30">McLeod, p. 30.</ref> This action prompted the Duyệt's officials—fearful of their positions and security under the central system—to launch a revolt under the leadership of his adopted son Lê Văn Khôi.<ref name="m30"/><ref name="b"/> Historical opinion is divided with scholars contesting whether the humiliation of Duyệt or the loss of southern autonomy was the main catalyst.<ref name="b">Buttinger, pp. 322–324.</ref>
On the night of May 18, 1833, Duyệt's supporters took control of the citadel, executing Nguyên and his subordinates. They then held a torch-lit ceremony at Duyệt's tomb, during which his adopted son Khôi formally rejected the imperial authority of Minh Mang and declared his support for An Hoa, the son of Prince Cảnh. On the same evening, Khoi's men assassinated [[Nguyen Van Que]], the newly appointed Governor-General who was overseeing the integration of the south into the central administration. All of the centrally appointed officials were killed or fled the citadel.<ref name="m30"/> Surprise attacks caught the imperial garrisons off guard and within three days, all six southern provinces were in the hands of Khoi's forces.<ref name="m30"/> Khoi convinced a French priest named [[Joseph Marchand]] to come and stay within the citadel, hoping that his presence would win over support from the local Catholics.<ref name="b"/> Khoi's support of An Hoa was also calculated to gain Catholic support, because Canh had converted to Catholicism.<ref name="m14">McLeod, p. 14.</ref> He further called on Catholics to congregate in the citadel under his protection.<ref name="m30"/> Vietnamese priests went on to lead Catholic armies in fighting off imperial forces as well providing messengers to communicate with the world outside their besieged citadel.<ref name="m31">McLeod, p. 31.</ref> [[File:Phoenix Citadel.png|thumb|250px|Layout of the Citadel of Saigon after 1835. In this time, Citadel of Saigon was also called ''Thành Phụng'' (''Citadel of Phoenix'' in Vietnamese). This drawing was taken from the book ''Dai Nam Nhat Thong Chi'' (literally ''Dai Nam Administrative Repertory''), official administrative repertory of Nguyễn Dynasty.]] In mid-1834, the imperial forces managed to finally repel the Siamese invaders and gained the upper hand over the rebels, regaining control of the southern countryside and besieging the rebel fortress.<ref name="b"/> Although Khôi died during the siege in November 1834,<ref name="b"/> the rebels defending the citadel of Saigon held out against imperial troops until September, 1835.<ref name="m30"/> The rebel commanders put to death. In all, between 500 and 2,000 citadel defenders were captured and executed, including Marchand.<ref name="b"/>
== Second structure == Following the revolt, Minh Mạng ordered that the citadel be dismantled in 1835. He then ordered that a new citadel be built in its place, which was still square-shaped, but only had four towers. The six outer towers in the original citadel were discarded.<ref name="m526">Mantienne, p. 526.</ref> The destruction was seen as retribution for its use in the revolt. The new citadel, rebuilt in 1836,<ref name="m526"/> was much smaller and was much more susceptible to enfilade bombardment from a nearby waterway.<ref name="m27"/> The length of the square sides was {{convert|475|m|abbr=on}}, surrounded by {{convert|20|m|abbr=on}} high walls, made from granite rocks, brick and earth.<ref name="n178">Nguyen, p. 178.</ref> The fort was surrounded by deep moats.
== French invasion and destruction == {{Main|Siege of Saigon}} [[File:Pierre Louis - Charles Rigault de Genouilly.jpg|thumb|Rigault de Genouilly captured the citadel in a French attack in 1859.]] The process of Vietnam's colonisation began in 1858 when a Franco-Spanish force landed at [[Da Nang]] in central Vietnam and attempted to proceed to the capital Hue.<ref>Chapuis, p. 48.</ref> After becoming tied down, they sailed to the less defended south, targeting Saigon.<ref name="m91">McLeod, p. 91.</ref> The southern offensive started on February 10, 1859 with a naval bombardment of [[Vũng Tàu]]. Within six days, the Europeans had levelled 12 Vietnamese fortresses and three river barriers. They then sailed along the [[Saigon River]] to the mouth of the Citadel of Saigon and opened fire with naval artillery from close range.<ref name="m44">Marr, p. 44.</ref> The fort was manned by 1,000 soldiers and stored enough rice to feed 10,000 defenders for an entire year.<ref name="n179"/>
On February 17, 1859, the French warships opened fire on the citadel with artillery. This attack focused on the southeastern corner of the citadel, where most of the Vietnamese artillery had been installed.<ref name="n179"/> The Vietnamese artillery commanders had miscalculated and had set up their cannons incorrectly, firing at excessively high angles. The cannons were not easily adjusted and thus the Vietnamese firepower was misdirected and ineffective.<ref name="n179"/> At around 10:00, Captain Des Pallieres led 300 French soldiers in an infantry attack. They used bamboo ladders to scale the walls under artillery support from the river. The defenders were caught off guard by this manoevre and many fled in chaos.<ref name="n179"/>
Most of the Vietnamese defence personnel were concentrated at the eastern gate of the citadel, where they stubbornly fought off the French. [[Rigault de Genouilly]] led 500 French troops in hand-to-hand combat for seven hours, having used explosives to breach the citadel. At 14:00, the French seized control of the citadel.<ref name="n179">Nguyen, p. 179.</ref> Two hours later, de Genouilly declared the citadel as the new general headquarters of the French forces.<ref name="n180">Nguyen, p. 180.</ref> The French seized a large arsenal. This included more than 200 cannons, 20,000 hand-held weapons such as firearms, pistols and swords, 100 tons of munitions, 80,000 tons of rice and 130,000 francs in cash.<ref name="n180"/> [[Potassium nitrate|Saltpetre]], shot and sulphur were also seized.<ref name="m27"/> The Vietnamese material losses were estimated to be around 20 million francs.<ref name="n180"/> The citadel commander fled to another village before committing suicide.<ref name="n180"/> [[File:Đại bác thành Gia Định.jpg|thumb|A remaining cannon of Citadel of Saigon]] The Vietnamese attempted to reclaim the citadel by sending reinforcements. [[Vĩnh Long]] and [[Mỹ Tho]] sent 1,800 and 800 troops respectively, but French shelling prevented them from reaching the scene.<ref name="n181">Nguyen, p. 181.</ref> This left the 5,800-strong local self-defence militia to combat the French. These militia engaged in ambushing French patrols near the citadel, as well as evacuating local inhabitants, in order to create an open space close to their target.<ref name="n182">Nguyen, p. 182.</ref> The local militia were supported by wealthy southern landowners, who supplied them with food and resources.<ref name="n183">Nguyen, p. 183.</ref>
The French soldiers charged with holding the citadel soon became stretched by the guerrilla attacks on the military installation. De Genouilly had decided to withdraw some of his forces back to central Vietnam. In addition, the inland position of the French forces lessened their technological advantage. As a result, the French decided to evacuate and destroy the fort. This was achieved on March 8. Captain Deroulede used 32 chests of explosives.<ref name="n184"/> He also razed the citadel by setting the rice granary ablaze, along with the weapons and munitions. The resulting fire was said to have smoldered for a further three years.<ref name="m27">Marr, p. 27.</ref><ref name="n184">Nguyen, p. 184.</ref> The French withdrew to the outskirts of the city, before returning to central Vietnam.<ref name="n185">Nguyen, p. 185.</ref>
